channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Princess Cristina of Spain Is Charged in Corruption Case
item.description: A judge concluded that there was sufficient evidence that she profited personally and helped her husband with his suspect business activities.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Princess Cristina, sister of King Felipe VI who gained the throne last week and is trying to rebuild the monarchy’s reputation, faces trial on corruption charges.

item.title: Princess Christina of Spain Charged in Corruption Case
item.description: A judge found that there was sufficient evidence to believe she profited both personally and helped her husband with his suspect business activities.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: No Verdict on Further Charges Against Coulson in British Hacking Case
item.description: Andy Coulson, the onetime editor and former aide to Prime Minister David Cameron, was facing charges relating to payments to police officers for royal telephone directories.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Andy Coulson, former editor in Rupert Murdoch’s media empire who later became a spokesman for Prime Minister David Cameron, departs the Old Bailey, London’s main criminal court, on Wednesday.

item.title: North Korea Warns U.S. Over Film Mocking Its Leader
item.description: A government spokesman called “The Interview,” a comedy in which two Americans are recruited to kill Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, “an act of war.”
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Spanish Princess Charged in Corruption Case
item.description: A court upheld corruption charges against Princess Cristina, sister of King Felipe VI who gained the throne last week, and her husband.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: String of Explosions Hit Cairo’s Subway
item.description: At least eight people were hurt in northern Cairo when homemade explosive devices blew up at four subway stations and a courthouse on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Iran Secretly Sending Drones and Supplies into Iraq, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: The effort, which is not coordinated with American military assistance, appears to be directed by the head of Iran’s paramilitary Quds Force.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Merkel Shrugs Off Cameron’s Opposition to Juncker
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel said any attempt by Britain to block the nomination of Jean-Claude Juncker as the next head of the European Commission would fail.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Israel’s Puppy, Tony Blair
item.description: As a Middle East envoy, Blair has advanced his consultancy business more than he has helped Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By MARWAN BISHARA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: To: Chinese Embassy, United States; Address: No. 1 Liu Xiaobo Plaza
item.description: A congressional committee in the United States has approved a measure that would rename a street outside the Chinese Embassy in Washington “Liu Xiaobo Plaza,” after the imprisoned political dissident.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The Chinese Embassy in Washington may find itself at a new address.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Turning From Europe’s Past
item.description: Amid war’s monuments, let’s think of the Continent’s future.
item.dc:creator: By NIKOS KONSTANDARAS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Unveils New Map of South China Sea
item.description: A vertical map representing China’s claims in the South China Sea shows two disputed clusters of islands entirely within Chinese territory.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Scanning of New Area Begins in Malaysia Jet Search
item.description: A ship has begun mapping the Indian Ocean floor in preparation for a renewed search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, though the effort has been complicated by a lack of satellite images.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: India Ink: Sanskrit Newspaper Sees Business Model in New Government
item.description: The editor of a Sanskrit-language weekly newspaper hopes to gain valuable advertising revenue from the newly elected Hindu nationalist government.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: The front page of the Sanskrit newspaper Sajal Sandesh after Narendra Modi's party won the general election, with a headline that translates to "Miracle, Miracle, Miracle."

item.title: News Analysis: Shinzo Abe’s Bid to Shake Up Corporate Japan
item.description: A crosshatch of stock holdings allows Japan’s big corporations to protect one another from outside attempts to shake up management. The prime minister has taken aim at the practice.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Mr. Abe, Japan’s prime minister, has proposed untangling the protective mutual stockholdings among corporations.

item.title: Long Absent, Nuclear Expert Still Has Hold on Iran Talks
item.description: Without Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, who is believed to be leading Iran’s nuclear program, an agreement on negotiations will lack real understanding of how close Iran is to building a nuclear warhead.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Doubting Putin, Obama Prepares to Add Pressure
item.description: The Obama administration has drawn up plans to escalate sanctions against Russia by targeting its financial, energy and defense industries.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: A mechanic cleared debris Tuesday after overnight shelling at a coal mine in the Luhansk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: After Opening Way to Rebels, Turkey Is Paying Heavy Price
item.description: Many Turks now blame their government for facilitating the rise of extremists in Syria and the new insurgency in Iraq, including the kidnapping of 80 Turkish citizens.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two sons and two nephews of Mehmet Selim Karakan, center, were kidnapped by ISIS while trucking goods to Iraq from Turkey.

item.title: Kerry Implores Kurdish Leader to Join a Government and Not Break Away
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry urged the president of Iraq’s Kurdish autonomous region not to seek his own state and instead help form a government in Baghdad.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Masoud Barzani, the president of Iraq’s Kurdish autonomous region, on Tuesday in Erbil, Iraq.

item.title: World Briefing : Mexico: Cartel Leader Is Arrested
item.description: The head of the once-mighty Arellano Felix drug cartel, based in Tijuana, was arrested while watching Mexico’s soccer team play in the World Cup, Monte Alejandro Rubido, the federal police chief, said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Lawmakers’ Vote Advances Ban of Birth Control Procedures
item.description: Iran moved toward criminalizing vasectomies and tubal ligations on Tuesday as lawmakers approved a bill meant to counter a drop in the country’s population, the semi-official Iranian Students’ News Agency reported.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Deadly Attack on Plane
item.description: Gunmen fired on a plane as it was landing in the northern city of Peshawar on Tuesday night, striking a Pakistani passenger in the head in front of her young daughter and injuring three crew members.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Court Rules on End-of-Life Case
item.description: France’s highest administrative court, the Conseil d’État, ruled Tuesday that a feeding tube could legally be removed from a 38-year-old man in a persistent vegetative state, whose care has been part of a long, bitter public fight involving the country’s end-of-life legislation.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Harvard Scholar’s Body Cremated After Request for Burial in Iran Falters
item.description: A Harvard scholar who wanted to be buried in Iran, a request that angered hard-liners there, has been cremated by his family in Boston, the Iranian news media reported Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Questions Rebels Use to Tell Sunni From Shiite
item.description: How can the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria tell whether a person is a Sunni or a Shiite? From accounts, it seems they often ask a list of questions.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
